description.plain:
“Why Am I Like This” is the lead single of Orla Gartland’s third EP of the same name. Dedicated to the “overthinking anxious types,” the track outlines some events Orla wished played out differently:

The verses detail a couple of brief, regular real-life moments where I wish I’d acted differently, where I’d said or done something else in the moment.

body.plain:
“Why Am I Like This” is the lead single of Orla Gartland’s third EP of the same name. Dedicated to the “overthinking anxious types,” the track outlines some events Orla wished played out differently:

The verses detail a couple of brief, regular real-life moments where I wish I’d acted differently, where I’d said or done something else in the moment.

annotations: I’ll be there in the corner, thinking right over
This is a play on words, of “overthinking” which happens to be the title of a demo released on the Freckle Season EP Overthinking (Demo)
Oh-oh, it’s like I’m looking down from the ceiling above
Dissasociation is often described as “being in the 3rd person”, people who suffer from dissasociation often describe the experience the way this lyric does- “looking down at myself from above”

Then we got tattoos by the coast
 And I just stood there just like a ghost

In the early version of this track, the final lines of this verse were:

‘Cause I’ve been a little bit stupid lately
But it doesn’t come all that naturally to me

Two weeks before the video was posted, on March 30th, Orla got her first tattoo, chosen “because it’s always gonna be OK:”



During this time, Orla was touring with Dodie, as her lead guitarist. Dodie, (who got 2) along with drummer Ross Craib, (also got 2) Siobháin Brackenridge and bassist Pete Daynes all got matching tattoos the same night Orla got hers. All five were tattooed at No Friends Tattoo Club in Brighton, a seaside town on England’s southern coast.

description.plain:
“More Like You” is the second single released from Orla Gartland’s upcoming album release in 2021 (Album title and release date as of now unconfirmed).

The song was first played for the general public in an “Indoor Season” show on her youtube channel, but a demo version can be found on her patreon, also known as Orla’s Secret Demo Club.

body.plain:
“More Like You” is the second single released from Orla Gartland’s upcoming album release in 2021 (Album title and release date as of now unconfirmed).

The song was first played for the general public in an “Indoor Season” show on her youtube channel, but a demo version can be found on her patreon, also known as Orla’s Secret Demo Club.

songs.title: More Like You (Piano Version)

songs.full_title: More Like You (acoustic) by Orla Gartland
songs.title: More Like You (acoustic)

annotations: So maybe I won’t take you on as such a threat

gartland stated that she wrote this song after a new person who has popped into her best friend’s life. gartland describes her insecure feelings and jealousy, posing this new person as a threat to her friendship.

Oh, I heard it from a woman on the internet
 She told me to eat well and try to love myself

This line refers to a lyric from her previous single Pretending,

Smokey brown eyeshadow
I learnt it from a woman on the internet

The woman on the internet is a stranger. This line is satirical commentary criticizing the often false and reductive advice that positivity influencers post online. If it were this easy, then we would have probably already done it and we would be happy now. Instead, we feel inadequate.

“Woman on the Internet” was also revealed to be the title of her debut album on June 9 after a teaser video flashing the title was shared on her Instagram and Twitter. From these lyrics and that of her previous single Pretending, many fans speculated that “Woman on the Internet” would be the title of her debut album.

description.plain:
“Oh God” was debuted live as an unreleased track during Orla Gartland’s November 2019 UK/EU tour in support of her 2019 EP Why Am I Like This?.

The earliest recording available on Youtube comes from her November 12 show in Leeds.

song.embed_content: Read “​oh GOD” by Orla Gartland on Genius
song.title: ​oh GOD

album.full_title: Freckle Season / Why Am I Like This? (Vinyl) by Orla Gartland
album.name: Freckle Season / Why Am I Like This? (Vinyl)

body.plain:
“Oh God” was debuted live as an unreleased track during Orla Gartland’s November 2019 UK/EU tour in support of her 2019 EP Why Am I Like This?.

The earliest recording available on Youtube comes from her November 12 show in Leeds.

annotations:
No, oh
 (I don’t want to think about it, I don’t want to think about it)
 Can’t control it
 (I don’t want to think about it)
 Oh, God
 No, oh
 (I don’t want to think about it, I don’t want to think about it)
 Can’t control it
 (I don’t want to think about it, I don’t want to think about it)

At this point in the song, the tempo picks up and the beat gets louder and more techno to reflect the internal struggle Orla is experiencing as she attempts to accept who she is and her past.

“Can’t control it” may be in reference to a feeling that a lot of lgbtq+ people feel when coming to terms with their identities and trying to suppress who they are.
I’m swallowed up by this Catholic guilt
Gartland stated on twitter that this song was about how guilty she felt after being with another woman, as well as coming out as bisexual.
Laying there motionless each night

This, as with the previous line, could be in reference to herself, a past lover, or God himself.

If it were herself or a lover, they lay motionless because the thoughts are consuming them. They can’t sleep; they’re lost in the memory of their past, “sinful” experience.

On the other hand, if it were God, as the first line of this verse implies, it could be his presence in Heaven as him laying motionless. The following two lines wouldn’t make as much sense in reference to him, but it could then switch perspectives to Orla or a past lover.
I look at you and I know how I felt

Orla – or rather, the speaker – could be saying “you” in reference to her younger self. She sees this person she was but is no longer, and she recognizes the feelings she had and wasn’t fully able to deal with.

She could also be saying “you” in reference to a past lover. Being reminded of their face, looking at photos, or seeing them in her mind’s eye brings back the feelings she used to have, or possibly still does.
This can’t be easy on his side
This line has dual meanings. It could either be referring to a past lover, or it could be referring to God himself (as referenced by the “Catholic guilt” and “Oh, God”).

We kissed on the bed
 It messed with my head
 Does that mean nothing to you?

This possibly alludes to an experience where Orla kissed a girl and it was with someone more experienced with lgbtq+ relationships who didn’t feel the same rush as Orla. Here she feels like her counterpart is underreacting to the occurrence.

If I always do what I’m told
 I’ll be bitter at 50 years old
 I wasted my youth
 Wasted my time
 Wasted my worry on the little things
This adds to the guilt felt with promiscuity and listening to “elders” and all of society’s rules leaves people, overall, sadder, bitter, and bogged down.
Oh, God

The intonation of the refrain “Oh, God” changes throughout the song.  Sometimes it sounds more straightforwardly like dread, or anger, but sometimes it wavers in-between shame and orgasm.  The subtle control in these spoken-word sections mirror the themes of the overall song.  We hear the mixture of pleasure and guilt, of desire and shame, and of the whole mixture of emotions that she went through.
I look at her

Since oh GOD is about deliberate obfuscation from herself and others, Orla is purposefully vague about what she “doesn’t wanna think about.” However, she decides to insert into the last pre-chorus:
1. “thinking,” a bridging word between Verse 2 and the pre-chorus
2. the pronoun “her”

Depending on who is “thinking,” Orla or the man who’s referenced in Verse 2, this last pre-chorus could be either:
1. Revealing the source of the “Catholic guilt,” a woman who she’s had a decidedly un-Catholic relationship with, or,
2. Describing the thoughts of a man who is also thinking about a former lover, be it Orla or Orla’s current lover thinking of some other third party

I’m inclined to believe that she’s revealing a queer romance. If it was “his” point of view, we’re taking the narrative from a personal “I don’t wanna think about it” experience to… a known shared experience? that is also personal? Since there aren’t any other hints to the activity, this makes the song more confusing and muddled, leaving us with more questions than answers. This theory contrasts to the more coherent lgbtq+ theory, one that musically describes a burst of clarity emerging via a nighttime anxiety spiral.

Additionally, there’s a narrative history of revealing the pronoun late in the song, whispering the truth that was meant to be hidden.

Oh! And she posted this on Twitter in 2018:
https://twitter.com/orlagartland/status/1044148278596706305

It doesn’t necessarily mean she’s bisexual…. but well…. it heavily implies it.

Note: Feel free to comment if you do have real evidence that supports the heterosexual theory.

I don’t want to think about it
 I don’t want to think about it
 I don’t want to think about it
 I don’t want to think about it
 I don’t want to think about it
 I don’t want to think about it

Those memories keep going back to her, even though she tries to bury them deep down. The repetitiveness is a sign of her trying to distract her mind and leave aside the thoughts that keep her restless.

You’re Not Special, Babe Lyrics[Verse 1]

You

I know you feel like your life is one big mistake

[Chorus]
You're not special, babe (No!)
I know you feel like your life is one big mistake
I am right there on your side
You're not special, babe (No!)
'Cause we all go from heartbreak to happy to heartbreak
Some things just don't change

[Outro]

description.plain:
“You’re Not Special, Babe” was released on July 7th, 2021, and is the fifth single for Orla Gartland’s upcoming album Woman On The Internet.

The song is written in a message to self style, acting as somewhat of a slap to reality—albeit a kind one.

annotations:
’Cause you’re not special, babe (No!)
 I know you feel like your life is one big mistake

Rather than being spoken to another person, these lines seem to be spoken to herself. It’s a reminder that as much as she feels like she is the only one who feels the way she does, she’s not special in that way and many others feel the same or similar.

description.plain:
Less than four months after releasing her EP Why Am I Like This?, Orla was back again with “Did It To Myself”, a lyrically downcast song which sees Orla blaming herself for the way a relationship ended.

The song was first heard in August by a group of dedicated fans in the top tier of Orla’s patreon.

body.plain:
Less than four months after releasing her EP Why Am I Like This?, Orla was back again with “Did It To Myself”, a lyrically downcast song which sees Orla blaming herself for the way a relationship ended.

The song was first heard in August by a group of dedicated fans in the top tier of Orla’s patreon.

annotations:
I woke up to an empty bed
 I took a walk to clear my head
 I wished you were there instead
 But then I shook it off
After breaking up with her ex, Gartland feels strange waking up in an empty bed. But then she reminds herself that it was for the right reasons.

You said answer honestly
 And I went with option B
 I lost you and you lost me
 I can’t shake it off
After having a honest conversation with her ex, she decided to make the hard decision to end things.

Oh my god, you’re everything I know
 Let it sink in right now
 Oh my god, you’re everything I know
 Get ready for the comedown
She is having the realisation that this person was everything to her and her life revolved around them. Comedown almost refers to her feeling addicted to them like a drug.

I wonder, what are you doing now?
 Defeats the point of shutting you out
She still thinks about what her ex is up to, even after removing them from her life as much as possible. She finds it frustrating.

And now you’re living in my memory, living in my mouth
 Living in the four fucking walls of my house
She finds herself thinking of her ex all the time, wanting to talk about them, seeing them around her house.

What the hell did I used to do?
 I’m even starting to speak like you
After being in a relationship of any sort, you start picking up the way someone speaks. Gartland is frustrated, feeling like she has lost her identity and doesn’t know how to go back to who she was.

I know I did it to myself
 I know I did it to myself
 I know I did it to myself
 I know I
Gartland knows she broke up with her ex, the repitition is telling us she has to remind herself that she did it for the right reasons.

I feel like a let-down
 To not be your friend now
After most break-ups, people decide to stay ‘friends’ with their exes. In this line Orla Gartland says she feels insufficient after deciding not to be friends with her ex.

Codependency Lyrics[Verse 1]
I'm not happy if you're not happy
And I swear that you're always sad
You're pathetic, I resent it

But it's not your fault
Your life, it isn't mine

I think I'm the problem with you
And I don't know what to do
And I see that's why they call it codependency

[Verse 2]

And made you say that I'm good at singin'
I keep diggin'

Sometimes I wanna die
And I realise

[Chorus]
That I'm the problem with you
And I don't know what to do

That's why they call it codependеncy

[Bridge]
And I'm cryin' out to be more
Than some little dog that just sits around
At your feet, that's not me

'Cause you fucked up too

'Cause it's true

That I'm the problem with you
And I don't know what to do
And I see that's why they call it codependency
That's why they call it codependency
That's why they call it codependency

[Outro]

And I swear that you're always sad
You're not happy if I'm not happy
And I swear that I'm always sad1Embed

annotations: Three words, two hearts, one maybe

The three words refer to the words “I love you,” as confirmed by Orla. In this instance, Orla told a boy she loved him and the statement wasn’t reciprocated, hence the “one maybe” – he was unsure about his feelings.

I feel like all of this has aged me
 Right on the edge of 22

This a reference to the Stevie Nicks‘ song “Edge of Seventeen.”

Speaking to tmrw Magazine, Orla said that while touring with Dodie Clark, she heard the song multiple times in shops and it stuck in her head:

I was like “this is so weird, I’ve heard this song so much…” I was like “I really love this Stevie Nicks song and I would love to have a song that has that sort of mood to it!” There was no kind of gritty, bitey, angsty ones and I feel like the driving rhythm of this song feels very angsty to me.

Stevie Nicks' aura seemed to be following Orla around, as she told Coup De Magazine:

On the studio wall (where Orla wrote the track) there’s a little poster of Steve Nicks that says, “What would Stevie do?” – I was definitely channeling some “Edge of Seventeen” vibes whilst we brought the song to life.

description.plain: A piano-backed ballad part of Orla’s EP Freckle Season, “Heavy” deals with Orla’s feelings on a breakup. It was released as the third single of Freckle Season in January 2020.

song.embed_content: Read “Heavy” by Orla Gartland on Genius
song.title: Heavy

album.full_title: Freckle Season / Why Am I Like This? (Vinyl) by Orla Gartland
album.name: Freckle Season / Why Am I Like This? (Vinyl)

body.plain: A piano-backed ballad part of Orla’s EP Freckle Season, “Heavy” deals with Orla’s feelings on a breakup. It was released as the third single of Freckle Season in January 2020.

annotations:
And I’ve been kissing different faces just to make it a reality
 Oh, I did it for the therapy
 But I felt alone
Rebounding right after a hard breakup can be extremely hard-trying to force romance or sex when you just miss your ex can make you feel even more isolated
But you’re in every stripey t-shirt that I own
She associates this person with stripey clothing, so whenever she sees her stripey tshirts, she sees them in her head.

’Cause I really thought that we’d be cool
 Some exception to the rule
 But honestly, I think it has to be this heavy
Sometimes you hope a relationship can last, even though there are lots of things that just mean it cannot work. But then you have the realisation that it really cannot.

Do you think about me at night?
 When the sky is losing light
 I swear my head fills up with memories every time
 Are you moving on with your life?
 Did you find a job you like?
 Always thought you could do anything

Gartland still cares about this person even though they are no longer in her life. She thinks about them before she sleeps. She hopes they are doing well and looks up to them even though she is no longer with them.
So tell me why this has to be so heavy

This refers back to the song title, named for Orla’s heavy (i.e. melancholy) feelings for someone she “desperately [missed]”:

“I wrote [Heavy] last year when I was right in the thick of desperately missing someone & feeling sad as heck.”
—Orla Gartland, Orla Gartland drops lyric video for new single ‘Heavy’, Hot Press

And I’ve been trying to train my mind to put you in another category
 But it’s still not coming naturally
It can be difficult to accept significant changes to an established relationship. It takes time and effort, and if you’re not careful it can be easy to fall into old habits and patterns of thought.
Grand Designs

Grand Designs is a British TV series about unconventional custom-built homes. This line evokes the image of two young people together on a sofa watching TV.

Relatedly, the phrase “grand design” refers to big plans or projects. This sets up an interesting synergy with the more down-to-earth literal meaning which may not be apparent to non-British listeners.

You can't force him to love you
He can't expect you to be alright
With all the bullshit he gives you
You wake up drenched in mosquito bites

But if you fall in love with a girl
She'll make you feel like the world is on your shoulder
When you're holding her hand
The first time that you kiss, you'll smell lilacs on her lips
And when you need a little space
You know that she'll understand
[Chorus: Cavetown & Orla Gartland]
That boy, let him go
Lights are on, but no one's home
Enough's enough, find your pearl
And fall in love with a girl

[Verse 2: Orla Gartland]
You know it's okay to want more
You know it's okay to clench your fists
When your head is all tanglеd up
Nobody else makes you feel likе this
I don't wanna be your wakeup call (Wakeup call)
I don't wanna be on your bedroom wall (Bedroom wall)
No one ever said boys do it better
So I wrote you a letter
Saying, "Why don't you leave him and come here and kiss me instead?"

[Pre-Chorus: Cavetown & Orla Gartland]
I heard you fell in love with a girl
She makes you feel like the world is on your shoulder
When you're over your head
She'll love you carefully, drawing letters on the beach
And you finally found a place where you don't have to pretend

[Chorus: Cavetown & Orla Gartland]
That boy, let him go
Lights are on, but no one's home
Enough's enough, find your pearl
And fall in love with a girl

And fall in love with a girlEmbed

songs.full_title: ​fall in love with a girl by Cavetown (Ft. ​beabadoobee)
songs.title: ​fall in love with a girl

annotations: Lights are on, but no one’s home

These lines most likely reference the deceitful relationship of the boy and the girl in this song. The boy may act like her loves her, but he doesn’t.

It could also reference the fact that the girl is trying to love him but just doesn’t feel it.
You wake up drenched in mosquito bites

These lyrics are probably the most cryptic in the song.

It could be referring to something nagging you. Maybe the girl in this song wakes up every day only to have a nagging feeling in her mind that she doesn’t like this boy and would rather be with a girl instead, much like a mosquito bite has a constant nagging itch until you can’t ignore it anymore.

Let me know what you think is happening!
